title: Norwegian Cruise Line Program Allows Passengers to Bid on Cabin Upgrades
text:
Norwegian Cruise Line Program Allows Passengers to Bid on Cabin Upgrades Norwegian Cruise Line Program Allows Passengers to Bid on Cabin Upgrades Subscribe January 20, 2017 
(4:57 p.m. EST) -- Travelers booked on Norwegian Cruise Line sailings now have the opportunity to bid on cabin upgrades as part of the line's new Upgrade Advantage Program, which will roll out fleetwide by March 2017. 
Debuting first on Norwegian Escape, Norwegian Epic, Norwegian Breakaway, Norwegian Getaway and Pride of America on Feb. 8, the system will generate email-based alerts to qualifying booked passengers, based on a number of factors, including how much a particular passenger has already paid and the number of unbooked cabins remaining. 
The program, which was tested on a handful of ships in 2016, is designed to benefit both passengers and travel agents. Besides receiving alerts when upgrades are available, cruisers will have a better idea of how likely they are to actually receive one when they place a bid. Additionally, bidding fees start out low; if a low bid is accepted, cruisers can snag higher-level cabins for less money than they would have paid to book that type of stateroom in the first place. 
The only potential drawback to the program is that bids can be placed on cabin type (ocean-view, balcony, mini-suite, suite, The Haven) only -- not on specific categories within each type or on specific cabin numbers. 
Meanwhile, travel agents have the choice to opt out of the program, but those who do participate will receive commission on approved upgrade bids for their bookings without having to do any additional work. Agents are notified when alerts are issued to their clients and will be notified a second time only if a client places a bid and that bid is accepted. Show NCL Prices
